questions.text: One of your friends is teaching you about enhanced recovery after surgery. Which of the following he states is incorrect?

options.label: C
options.text: Reduction of hospital stay by 2-3 weeks

options.label: D
options.text: Beta-blockers are given after major surgery done under general anaesthesia to improve outcome

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Prolonged fasting is necessary According to ERAS protocol, Prolonged fasting is not necessary as it delays recovery

Highyeild:

ERAS is evidence based on the strong scientific rationale for avoiding unmodulated exposure to stress, prolonged fasting and excessive administration of intravenous (saline) fluids Reductions in length of hospital stay after surgery of 30–50% are common Widespread adoption of minimal access (e.g. laparoscopic) surgery is a key change in surgical practice that can reduce the magnitude of surgical injury and enhance the rate of patients’ return to homeostasis and recovery. Modulating the stress/inflammatory response at the time of surgery may have long-term sequelae over periods of months or longer. For example, 𝝱- blockers are associated with improved short- and long-term survival after major surgery , perhaps by modulating the effects of the hyperadrenergic state induced by surgical stress. In ‘open’ surgery the use of epidural analgesia to reduce pain, block the cortisol stress response and attenuate postoperative insulin resistance may, via effects on the body’s protein economy, favourably affect many of the patient-centred outcomes that are important to postoperative recovery. However, because of the reduction in wound size and tissue trauma, it should be noted that epidural analgesia is no longer recommended for laparoscopic surgery . Patient-controlled analgesia is usually sufficient and avoids the fluid shifts and hypotension seen with epidurals. Adjuncts such as ‘one-shot’ spinal diamorphine and/or a 6–12-hour infusion of intravenous lidocaine have been suggested to be opiate sparing, to improve gut function and to enhance overall recovery

questions.text: A chronic smoker comes with complaints of pain in his legs after walking 100 metres. On examination, he has an absent pulse in the bilateral dorsalis pedis, anterior tibial, and posterior tibial arteries, but no gangrene is present. Intermittent claudication is implicated. Which of the following statements is true regarding this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Pain is more at night and sleep

options.label: B
options.text: Development of pain on the 1st step of walking

options.label: C
options.text: Pain aggravated by standing and relieved by bending forward

options.label: D
options.text: Pain develops after walking some distance and relieved by rest

questions.correct_answer: D. Pain develops after walking some distance and relieved by rest
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pain develops after walking some distance and relieved by rest In intermittent claudication , pain develops after walking some distance and is relieved by rest

Highyeild:

Intermittent claudication occurs as a result of anaerobic muscle metabolism and is classically described as debilitating cramp-like pain felt in muscles that is: Brought on by walking Not present on taking the first step (unlike osteoarthritis) Relieved by rest in both the standing and sitting positions, usually within 5 minutes (unlike nerve compression from a lumbar intervertebral disc prolapse or osteoarthritis of the spine or spinal stenosis, which are typically relieved only when resting in the sitting position for longer than 5 minutes)

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Rest pain: As disease progression occurs the claudication distance decreases and perfusion to the leg may be so severely compromised that anaerobic respiration occurs even at rest ( pain worse at night and may be lessened by hanging foot out of bed or by sleeping in chair)

questions.text: A 60 year old male patient complains of numbness of both lower limbs. On examination Romberg test is positive with broad based gait and loss of proprioception of both lower limbs. He also has a history of low BP, hypothyroidism and gastrectomy for gastric cancer a year back. Which of the following deficiency can cause the current condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Vitamin B12 deficiency The given neurological symptoms following gastrectomy is due to Vitamin B12 deficiency ( due to loss of parietal mass ) and it requires replacement routinely

Highyeild:

The most common metabolic defect appearing after gastrectomy is anemia (related to iron deficiency (more common) or impairment in vitamin B12 metabolism) Megaloblastic anemia from vitamin B12 deficiency only rarely develops after partial gastrectomy but is dependent on the amount of stomach removed. Vitamin deficiency occurs secondary to poor absorption of dietary vitamin B12 because of the lack of intrinsic factor. Patients undergoing subtotal gastrectomy should be placed on lifelong vitamin B12 supplementation. If a patient develops a macrocytic anemia, serum vitamin B12 levels should be obtained and, if abnormal, treated with long-term vitamin B12 therapy

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Folic acid deficiency causes fatigue , mouth ulcers, cognitive changes , headache, palpitations. Option: C. Initial symptoms of B1 deficiency include anorexia, irritability, and difficulties with short-term memory. With prolonged thiamine deficiency, patients may endorse loss of sensation in the extremities, symptoms of heart failure including swelling of the hands or feet, chest pain related to demand ischemia, or feelings of vertigo, double vision, and memory loss Option: D. Transferrin deficiency may be due to iron deficiency anemia or inadequate production in liver and symptoms include fatigue, headache, spooning of nails, sore tongue, dizziness etc.,

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with acute epigastric pain and fever. He has a past history of cholelithiasis. On examination, abdominal guarding and rigidity are present. His serum amylase and lipase are raised and the patient has leukocytosis. What is true regarding his condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Serum amylase remains elevated even after 30 days of resolution of acute pancreatitis

options.label: B
options.text: Serum lipase is more specific than serum amylase

options.label: D
options.text: Increase in the level of serum lipase is directly proportional to the severity

questions.correct_answer: B. Serum lipase is more specific than serum amylase
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Serum lipase is more specific than serum amylase The given history and laboratory values points towards diagnosis of pancreatitis ( could be due to gallstone induced) Serum lipase is more specific and sensitive than serum amylase as serum amylase can be elevated in other conditions such as peptic ulcer disease, mesenteric ischemia, salpingitis and macroamylasemia

Highyeild:

Acute pancreatitis The major causes are biliary calculi ( 50 to 70 % patients ) and alcohol abuse ( 25% cases) Clinical Presentation Pain - develops quickly and reaches maximum intensity within minutes and persist for hours or even days and it is severe , constant and refractory to usual doses of analgesics, which is first experienced in epigastrium but may be localized to either upper quadrant or felt diffusely Nausea , repeated vomiting , retching Hiccoughs On Examination Tachypnea , tachycardia , hypotension may be present with temperature - normal or subnormal Mild icterus ( gallstone pancreatitis) Acute swinging pyrexia ( cholangitis) Bleeding into fascial planes , may cause bluish discolouration of flanks ( Gray Turner sign) Umbilicus ( Cullen sign ) Abdominal examination Distension ( ileus , rarely ascites with shifting dullness) Mass in epigastrium ( inflammation) Muscle guarding can be seen in upper abdomen, whereas rigidity is unusual Pleural effusion is seen in 10 to 20 % cases Investigations: Serum amylase levels three times above normal ( normal serum level do not exclude the disease if it is of delayed presentation) Serum lipase - more sensitive and specific than serum amylase Plain chest and abdominal X Ray – not diagnostic Non specific findings- sentinel loop , colon cut off sign , renal halo sign USG – to detect gallstones as potential cause Rule out acute cholecystitis To see if common bile duct dilated CT is done in those having mild attack on prognostic criteria EUS , MRCP – help in detecting stones in CBD

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. Serum amylase remains elevated only for shorter duration Option: C. Patients present with hypocalcemia and not hypercalcemia Option: D. Serum lipase level is not considered for severity

questions.text: An 84-year-old man with a history of stroke 2 years ago, who is on prolonged bed rest, develops a pressure ulcer with partial thickness skin loss and a clean base. What is the grade of his pressure sore?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Grade 2 Partial thickness skin loss ( involving dermis and epidermis ) is Grade 2

Highyeild:

Pressure sores occur as a result of friction or persisting pressure on soft tissues. They particularly affect the pressure points of recumbent patient, including sacrum , greater trochanter and heels Risk factors poor nutritional status, lack of mobility , dehydration and nerve block anesthesia technique Prevention To reduce risk intraoperatively - careful positioning and padding of patient Early mobilization of patient and regular inspection of pressure points Use of air mattress for high risk patients,

Random:

Explanation for other options: - Option: A. GRADE 1 - Intact skin with non-blanchable erythema of a localised area usually over bony prominence Option: C. GRADE 3 - Full thickness skin loss involving damage or necrosis of subcutaneous tissues extending to but not through underlying fascia, bone, tendon or joint capsule. Option: D. GRADE 4 - Full thickness skin loss with extensive destruction, tissue necrosis or damage to muscle, bone, tendon or joint capsule. Slough and eschar may be present

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with flank pain and painful micturition. The pain was relieved by IV analgesics given at a nearby primary healthcare centre. The patient is diagnosed with ureteric colic due to ureteric calculi. What is the best diagnostic modality in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

NCCT KUB Non-contrast CT (NCCT) is the investigation of choice for the diagnosis of stones. It allows for diagnosis of both radio-opaque and radiolucent stones with the exception of indinavir stones.

Highyeild:

The most common acute presentation of stone disease is ‘ ureteric colic ’. Small 3- to 5-mm calculi are usually responsible for ureteric colic and commonly lodge at the UVJ. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs and paracetamol are effective. Antispasmodic medications are not necessary to alleviate pain. Examination Abdominal examination may reveal renal angle tenderness. Pelvic examination is especially important in women to exclude tubo-ovarian pathology such as an ectopic pregnancy or twisted ovarian cyst Investigation : urinary examination, blood examination and diagnostic imaging. Majority have microscopic haematuria and pyuria. Pyuria may be sterile pyuria or due to infection An elevated leukocyte count suggests infection and may be an indication for starting antibiotics Pregnancy should be ruled out radiograph of the kidneys, ureters and bladder and US are done initially and Non-contrast CT is the investigation of choice

questions.text: During ward rounds, you see a patient who is admitted with Ca esophagus. What is the most likely presentation in this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: Dysphagia of solids followed by liquids

options.label: B
options.text: Dysphagia of liquids followed by solids

questions.correct_answer: A. Dysphagia of solids followed by liquids
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Dysphagia of solids followed by liquids Progressive dysphagia is the most common symptom. (progress from dysphagia to a solid, soft and eventually to a liquid diet)

Highyeild:

Esophageal carcinoma most commonly presents in the sixth and seventh decades of life. Squamous cell carcinoma and adenocarcinoma are the most common cell types Progressive dysphagia is the most common symptom, related to increasing luminal obstruction by cancer. ( dysphagia to a solid , soft and eventually to a liquid diet. ) There may often be anorexia, weight loss, odynophagia and regurgitation Hoarseness may indicate involvement of either recurrent laryngeal nerve. Early cancers are usually asymptomatic and are only picked up on endoscopy performed for other reasons Longitudinal submucosal spread (esophageal wall has a rich network of submucosal lymphatics) of cancer is common. Lymph node metastasis can involve the cervical area, the mediastinum as well as the perigastric/ coeliac axis

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Achalasia cardia present with dysphagia (to both solid and liquids), regurgitation and heartburn, although chest pain/ odynophagia is common in early stages

He was found to have ulcers in the jejunum and ileum. Gastric pH < 2, and gastrin levels after adequate cessation of PPIs are 10 times the normal value. Identify the lesion present and the boundaries of the triangle containing it:

options.label: A
options.text: Gastrinoma; triangle formed by common bile duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas

options.label: B
options.text: Insulinoma; triangle formed by cystic duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas

questions.correct_answer: C. Gastrinoma; triangle formed by cystic duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Gastrinoma; triangle formed by cystic duct, junction of D2-D3, neck and body of pancreas If the pH is <2 and the fasting serum gastrin is more than 10-fold elevated, the diagnosis of gastrinoma is confirmed The triangle is bounded by the lines connecting the cystic duct, the junction between the second and third portions of the duodenum, and the junction between the neck and body of the pancreas

Highyeild:

Zollinger Ellison syndrome is a condition that includes, fulminating ulcer diathesis in stomach, duodenum or atypical sites recurrent ulceration despite adequate therapy non beta islet cell tumors of pancreas ( gastrinoma) Hypergastrinemia results in peptic acid hypersecretion and refractory peptic ulcer disease. Duodenal ulcers are the most common, but jejunal ulceration may also occur presence of jejunal ulcers should raise suspicion for a gastrin-secreting PNET. Abdominal pain is the most common symptom and diarrhea is caused by large volume of gastric acid secretion Ninety percent of gastrinomas are located within the gastrinoma triangle Diagnosis It is considered in all patients with intractable peptic ulcers (especially jejunal ulcers), severe esophagitis, or persistent secretory diarrhea If the pH is <2 and the FSG is more than 10-fold elevated, the diagnosis is confirmed. If the FSG is less than 10-fold higher, a secretin provocation test should be performed False-negative results may be caused by the presence of Helicobacter pylori Treatment Surgical: all patients with sporadic gastrinoma without metastasis should have a surgical operation. In MEN 1/Gastrinoma, surgery is not recommended for patients with tumors <2 cm. Tumors >2 cm are enucleated Medical: PPI therapy is the management of choice

It more commonly presents as a solitary benign tumor, but it can sometimes be associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1). The classical diagnosis of insulinoma depends on satisfying the criteria of Whipple's triad, which remains the cornerstone of the screening process: Hypoglycemia (plasma glucose < 50 mg/dL); Neuroglycopenic symptoms; and Prompt relief of symptoms following the administration of glucose

questions.text: An elderly male patient comes with foul smelling breath and dysphagia. A barium swallow X-ray is attached. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Zenker's diverticulum The given clinical and radiological presentation of patient corresponds to Zenker's diverticulum

Highyeild:

Zenker diverticulum , protrudes posteriorly above cricopharyngeal sphincter through natural weak point ( dehiscence of Killian ) between oblique and horizontal fibers of inferior pharyngeal constrictor Pathophysiology: loss of coordination between pharyngeal contraction and opening of upper sphincter Clinical presentation include dysphagia , regurgitation , halitosis , Voice changes and respiratory infections are common in older patients In untreated cases , aspiration pneumonia or lung abscess is seen and this can be morbid in older patient Diagnosis is made by barium esophagogram ( diverticulum can be seen at level of cricothyroid cartilage , filled with barium resting posteriorly alongside esophagus) Esophageal manometry nor endoscopy is needed for diagnosis Conventional surgery involves open left cervical incision with diverticulectomy and cricopharyngeal myotomy Newer techniques include transoral introduction of linear stapler to divide septum in between diverticulum and true esophageal lumen Common channel is created and myotomy is in effect performed by stapler transection

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Achalasia is an esophageal motor disorder characterized by aperistalsis of the esophageal body and lack of relaxation of the lower sphincter in response to swallows. Barium swallow shows: bird beak appearance. Option: C. Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) is an abnormal fistulous communication between the esophagus and trachea. The diagnosis of TEF is considered in an infant with excessive salivation along with coughing or choking experienced at first oral feeding. In addition, curling of the orogastric tube at the level of thoracic inlet is pathognomonic for esophageal atresia +/- TEF. A maternal history of polyhydramnios is common, more often in isolated proximal atresia (86%) Option: D. Squamous cell cancer is the predominant histological cell. Progressive dysphagia is the most common symptom. Oesophageal cancer has a poor prognosis, which is in part related to late presentation; patients with early disease have no symptoms and the cancer tends to metastasis early

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient who is a known case of Hodgkin's lymphoma with a previous history of irradiation presents with right-sided thyroid swelling. FNAC reveals papillary carcinoma of the thyroid and there is no lymph node involvement. What is the next step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: Total thyroidectomy with modified radical neck dissection

options.label: D
options.text: Hemi-thyroidectomy with modified radical neck dissection

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Total thyroidectomy It is a case of radiation induced differentiated thyroid cancer Total thyroidectomy is the preferred treatment in these cases

Highyeild:

Surgery is the mainstay of therapy for Differentiated thyroid cancer (DTC) Ipsilateral thyroid lobectomy has become an acceptable alternative to total thyroidectomy for low-risk unilateral DTCs between 1 and 4 cm without extrathyroidal extension or evidence of metastatic disease , and it is the recommended surgical option for DTCs that are less than1 cm Total thyroidectomy is now the preferred evidence-based approach only for those DTCs at higher risk for recurrence and/or disease-specific mortality. Such scenarios include the following: Tumor at least 4 cm Gross extrathyroidal extension Evidence of metastatic disease Radiation-induced DTC Familial non medullary thyroid cancer Multifocal bilateral DTC. For DTCs with clinical and/or radiographic evidence of cervical lymph node metastases, therapeutic compartment-based lymph node dissection is recommended ATA guidelines suggest that prophylactic central neck dissection should be considered for certain higher risk patients with cN0 papillary thyroid carcinomas with more advanced primary tumors (T3 or T4) and clinically involved lateral neck nodes and/or if the information would be helpful in guiding additional therapy.

questions.text: Which is the most lethal nerve injury during thyroid surgery?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B/L RLN (complete) Complete bilateral Recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy may result in airway compromise

Highyeild:

COMPLICATIONS OF THYROIDECTOMY Vocal cord paralysis: Unilateral injury to RLN and resultant vocal cord paralysis can cause spectrum of problems with voice or swallowing Symptoms can include hoarse and breathy voice , vocal fatigue, dysphagia and aspiration bilateral RLN injury with vocal cord in midline position can lead to airway compromise and they need temporary or permanent tracheostomy Injury to EBSLN can lead to postoperative voice abnormalities due to its innervation of cricothyroid muscle and contribution to vocal cord tone Hypoparathyroidism Most common complication of thyroid surgery and in majority of cases they resolve within 6 months It is based on biochemical evidence of decreased serum calcium and/ or PTH levels , or symptomatic hypocalcemia requiring calcium or vitamin D supplementation All thyroidectomy specimens should be checked for inadvertently resected parathyroid tissue and if it is present and confirmed by either frozen section or intraoperative PTH aspiration, then the parathyroid tissue can be preserved on ice , minced and auto transplanted into sternocleidomastoid muscle prior to closure Post operative neck hematoma This typically presents with pain , oozing from incision, ecchymosis , firm swelling overlying the resection bed and incision and the patient can develop stridor with rapid airway collapse These usually occurs with first 6 hours after operation Incision should be made immediately wherever the patient is , if there is impending airway collapse and when opening the incision , all three layers of thyroidectomy bed - the skin , platysma and strap muscles must be opened to allow for maximal decompression

Extraedge:

Hypocalcemia (total serum concentration below 8.4 mg/dl or ionized calcium concentration < 4.5 mg/dL) It occurs in 1 to 2 % of patients after total thyroidectomy In permanent hypoparathyroidism , symptoms include mild circumoral or digital numbness and paraesthesia , carpopedal or laryngeal spasms and cardiac arrhythmias Chvostek’s sign : contraction of ipsilateral facial muscles on percussion of facial nerve Trousseau sign : development of carpopedal spasm secondary to occlusion of arm ( with blood pressure cuff usually)

questions.text: What is the T stage of this oral cavity tumour?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

T4a The tumor involves adjacent structure ( lip and floor of mouth) and according to TNM staging it is classified as T4a
